questions.text: On Head impulse test, for a Left vestibular neuritis patient, Saccade will be in which direction? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.correct_answer: C. Right on left head rotation
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Right on left head rotation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In left vestibular neuritis, head impulse tests reveal saccades towards the right when the head is rotated to the left due to the hypoactive left vestibular system.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about function of utricle and saccule? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Linear acceleration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The utricle and saccule are essential for detecting linear movements, helping the body maintain balance and posture in response to everyday activities and motion, while the cochlea and semicircular canals perform separate functions related to hearing and angular motion detection, respectively.

questions.text: A female presents with complaints of hearing loss and pulsatile tinnitus. Rinne’s test reveals conductive hearing loss. On otoscopy, a red and bulgy mass behind the intact tympanic membrane is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Glomus tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a red, pulsatile mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a patient with pulsatile tinnitus and conductive hearing loss is highly suggestive of a glomus tympanicum tumor, requiring detailed imaging for confirmation and planning of appropriate intervention strategies.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 345
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 345

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Battle sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Battle's sign is a significant diagnostic clue in trauma patients, signaling a possible basilar skull fracture. Recognition of this sign should prompt further diagnostic imaging and careful neurologic assessment to manage potential complications associated with such fractures.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition

questions.text: A teacher presents with the following condition and hoarseness of the voice. Identify.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vocal nodule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vocal nodules are benign, symmetrical lesions typically located at the junction of anterior 1/3 rd and posterior 2/3 rd of the vocal cords, often resulting from chronic vocal strain, and present with symptoms of hoarseness.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about laryngomalacia? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical management is required in most children

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Most common in newborn

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is characterized by inspiratory stridor that typically worsens in the supine position and is most commonly diagnosed in newborns. The condition generally resolves on its own without the need for surgical intervention in most cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old teacher presents with difficulty hearing lower frequencies, particularly male voices. On examination, the apex of the cochlea shows degenerative changes. Which of the following structures lies nearest to the affected region? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The affected structure in low-frequency hearing loss is the apical turn of the cochlea. Among the given options, the structure that lies nearest to this region is the helicotrema.
  • • According to von Bekesy's traveling wave theory:
  • • Sound waves create a traveling wave along the basilar membrane Different frequencies resonate at specific locations Lower frequencies are processed at the apex of the cochlea The helicotrema, located at the apex, connects scala vestibuli and scala tympani This region is crucial for low-frequency sound processing
  • • Sound waves create a traveling wave along the basilar membrane
  • • Different frequencies resonate at specific locations
  • • Lower frequencies are processed at the apex of the cochlea
  • • The helicotrema, located at the apex, connects scala vestibuli and scala tympani
  • • This region is crucial for low-frequency sound processing
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Oval Window : Located near the base of the cochlea, it's associated with high-frequency sound processing, not low-frequency hearing.
  • • Option B. Oval Window
  • • Option C. Round Window : Also located at the basal end of the cochlea, it's anatomically distant from the apex where low-frequency sounds are processed.
  • • Option C. Round Window
  • • Option D. Modiolus : While it runs through the center of the cochlea, it's not specifically closest to the apical region where low-frequency sounds are processed.
  • • Option D. Modiolus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the tonotopic organization of the cochlea is crucial for localizing hearing deficits. Low-frequency sounds are processed in the apex near the helicotrema, while high-frequency sounds are processed at the base near the oval and round windows.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes with excruciating ear pain, bloody discharge from the ear and HbA1c of 10. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Necrotizing otitis externa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a diabetic patient presenting with excruciating ear pain and bloody otorrhea, the diagnosis of necrotizing otitis externa should be considered, especially when the patient has a significantly elevated HbA1c, indicating poor glycemic control.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Scala tympani

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The scala tympani is the preferred site for electrode placement in cochlear implant surgery to ensure optimal auditory nerve stimulation, highlighting the importance of precision in surgical approaches to maximize the benefits of the implant.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant patient presented with complaints of worsening of hearing since the onset of pregnancy. On PTA the following graph was obtained. Which of the following statements regarding the disease is true? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained

options.label: B
options.text: Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss

options.label: C
options.text: Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery

options.label: D
options.text: Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

questions.correct_answer: D. Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Air travelling is a contraindication for surgery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient, being pregnant and experiencing worsening hearing loss, suggests otosclerosis. The provided PTA (Pure Tone Audiogram) shows a significant air-bone gap on the right side, indicating conductive hearing loss, which is consistent with otosclerosis.
  • • Definitely, air travel is contraindicated for patients post-stapedectomy for at least three months. The variations in middle ear pressure during ascent and descent can lead to displacement or dislocation of the prosthetic piston used in the surgery, making this statement true.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained: In otosclerosis, an As type of tympanogram (indicating reduced compliance of the middle ear system) is typically obtained, not Ad. Therefore, this statement is incorrect.
  • • Option A. Ad Type of tympanogram is obtained:
  • • Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss: A notch at 2000Hz on bone conduction is known as Carhart's notch, which is indicative of otosclerosis, not noise-induced hearing loss. Noise-induced hearing loss typically presents a notch at 4000Hz. Hence, this statement is incorrect.
  • • Option B. Notch at 2000Hz is indicative of Noise Induced hearing loss:
  • • Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery: Ménière's disease is indeed a contraindication for stapes surgery. The presence of Ménière's disease can lead to complications such as irritation of the saccule during the surgery, causing vertigo and giddiness. Thus, this statement is false.
  • • Option C. Associated Ménière's disease is not a contraindication for stapes surgery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Air travel is contraindicated for at least three months post-stapedectomy due to the risk of pressure-induced displacement or dislocation of the surgical prosthesis.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Montgomery T tube

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with throat pain, fever, and ear pain. He is diagnosed with recurrent tonsillitis. Which nerve is responsible for the ear pain in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.correct_answer: A. Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: In the presence of tracheal deviation as indicated on a chest X-ray, which procedure is the most difficult to perform? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheostomy can be more challenging in cases of tracheal deviation due to the altered position of the trachea, making the precise location for incision difficult to identify.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Electron microscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Test for mucociliary clearance is: Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Test for mucociliary clearance is: Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance. Radioisotope transport testing in vivo Measuring ciliary activity in vitro Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results. The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.
  • ➤ Saccharin with or without color test in vivo - Saccharin or another substance is placed in the nose, and the speed of transport into the nasopharynx is measured to calculate mucociliary clearance.
  • ➤ Radioisotope transport testing in vivo
  • ➤ Measuring ciliary activity in vitro
  • ➤ Nasal nitric oxide - Measuring exhaled nasal nitric oxide, which is mostly reduced in primary ciliary dyskinesia, is a good screening test for immotile-cilia syndrome with a good negative predictive value
  • ➤ Scintigraphy is the nuclear medicine equivalent of the dye disappearance test to assess functional and anatomic obstruction
  • ➤ Pulmonary radioaerosol mucociliary clearance: Mucociliary transport, which is reduced in these patients, can be measured in situ by administering an inhalation aerosol of colloid albumin or colloid sulfur tagged with technetium Tc 99. This test is generally not recommended owing to the high rate of false-positive results.
  • ➤ The charcoal method - a very small amount of charcoal is placed behind the head of the inferior turbinate. The pharynx is then observed to detect the presence of charcoal. Less commonly used.

questions.text: A surgeon is planning to use topical Mitomycin-C (10mg) in a post-surgical case. Which of the following conditions would most appropriately benefit from its application? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pterygium surgery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mitomycin-C is appropriate for pterygium surgery because:
  • • It acts as an antifibrotic agent that prevents post-surgical scarring and recurrence The antiproliferative properties help prevent fibrovascular regrowth Topical application during pterygium surgery significantly reduces recurrence rates Standard concentration of 0.02% (0.2 mg/ml) is used intraoperatively for 2-3 minutes
  • • It acts as an antifibrotic agent that prevents post-surgical scarring and recurrence
  • • The antiproliferative properties help prevent fibrovascular regrowth
  • • Topical application during pterygium surgery significantly reduces recurrence rates
  • • Standard concentration of 0.02% (0.2 mg/ml) is used intraoperatively for 2-3 minutes
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis: Requires systemic antifungal medications; Mitomycin-C has no role
  • • Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis:
  • • Option C. Adenoidectomy: A straightforward surgical removal procedure where antifibrotic agents are not indicated
  • • Option C. Adenoidectomy:
  • • Option D. Tympanoplasty: While it involves tissue repair, Mitomycin-C is not routinely used due to risks of ototoxicity
  • • Option D. Tympanoplasty:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitomycin-C has dual applications: antineoplastic (systemic use) and antifibrotic (topical use) Key applications in surgery focus on preventing post-surgical scarring and fibrosis Major ophthalmic applications include pterygium surgery and glaucoma filtering procedures Careful dosing and application time are crucial to prevent complications The drug's effectiveness is based on its ability to inhibit DNA synthesis and fibroblast proliferation
  • ➤ Mitomycin-C has dual applications: antineoplastic (systemic use) and antifibrotic (topical use)
  • ➤ Key applications in surgery focus on preventing post-surgical scarring and fibrosis
  • ➤ Major ophthalmic applications include pterygium surgery and glaucoma filtering procedures
  • ➤ Careful dosing and application time are crucial to prevent complications
  • ➤ The drug's effectiveness is based on its ability to inhibit DNA synthesis and fibroblast proliferation

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used for managing a patient with B/L external auditory canal atresia?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with bilateral external auditory canal atresia, BAHA is an excellent management option, leveraging bone conduction to bypass the outer and middle ear, thus facilitating hearing when traditional air-conduction devices cannot be used.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and found to have Rinne's negative at 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz, with Weber test lateralizing to the affected ear. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 45-60 dB

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In this case, the clinical findings suggest a more severe conductive hearing loss because:
  • • Rinne's test is negative at all frequencies (256Hz, 512Hz, and 1024Hz), indicating a significant air-bone gap When Rinne's test is negative for all three frequencies (256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz), it indicates an approximate hearing loss of 45-60dB Weber test lateralizing to the affected ear confirms conductive hearing loss This pattern suggests a more severe conductive component compared to the original question where Rinne was positive at 1024 Hz
  • • Rinne's test is negative at all frequencies (256Hz, 512Hz, and 1024Hz), indicating a significant air-bone gap
  • • When Rinne's test is negative for all three frequencies (256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz), it indicates an approximate hearing loss of 45-60dB
  • • Weber test lateralizing to the affected ear confirms conductive hearing loss
  • • This pattern suggests a more severe conductive component compared to the original question where Rinne was positive at 1024 Hz
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 30-45 dB: This gap would show Rinne positive at 1024 Hz
  • • Option A. 30-45 dB:
  • • Option B. 15-30 dB: This smaller gap would show Rinne positive at both 512 Hz and 1024 Hz
  • • Option B. 15-30 dB:
  • • Option D. >60 dB: Such severe losses are uncommon in typical conductive hearing loss and would likely have additional clinical findings
  • • Option D. >60 dB:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tuning fork test interpretation is frequency-dependent - the more frequencies showing negative Rinne, the larger the air-bone gap Sequential pattern to remember for conductive hearing loss severity: Negative at 256 Hz only → ~15-20 dB gap Negative at 256 Hz & 512 Hz → ~30-45 dB gap Negative at all frequencies (256, 512, 1024 Hz) → ~45-60 dB gap Weber test always lateralizes to the affected ear in conductive hearing loss, regardless of severity A comprehensive assessment should include multiple frequencies as testing at a single frequency can miss milder losses or underestimate severity
  • ➤ Tuning fork test interpretation is frequency-dependent - the more frequencies showing negative Rinne, the larger the air-bone gap
  • ➤ Sequential pattern to remember for conductive hearing loss severity: Negative at 256 Hz only → ~15-20 dB gap Negative at 256 Hz & 512 Hz → ~30-45 dB gap Negative at all frequencies (256, 512, 1024 Hz) → ~45-60 dB gap
  • ➤ Negative at 256 Hz only → ~15-20 dB gap Negative at 256 Hz & 512 Hz → ~30-45 dB gap Negative at all frequencies (256, 512, 1024 Hz) → ~45-60 dB gap
  • ➤ Negative at 256 Hz only → ~15-20 dB gap
  • ➤ Negative at 256 Hz & 512 Hz → ~30-45 dB gap
  • ➤ Negative at all frequencies (256, 512, 1024 Hz) → ~45-60 dB gap
  • ➤ Weber test always lateralizes to the affected ear in conductive hearing loss, regardless of severity
  • ➤ A comprehensive assessment should include multiple frequencies as testing at a single frequency can miss milder losses or underestimate severity

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Upper airway examination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheostomy tubes are not used for examining the upper airway as they do not provide access or visibility to upper airway structures such as the nasal passages, pharynx, or larynx. Instead, tools like laryngoscopes or endoscopes are employed for this purpose.

questions.text: A male cattle breeder from South India presents with frank, intermittent epistaxis. The description of the nasal examination is provided below. A biopsy was conducted, and the histopathological examination findings are depicted as presented below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients presenting with polypoidal nasal masses, especially if there is a history of exposure to contaminated water. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy revealing characteristic sporangia, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient arrives at the clinic with complaints of nasal obstruction on the right side and sporadic occurrences of blood-stained nasal discharge. The CT scan results are depicted in the image provided. What might be the potential underlying reason for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inverted Papilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inverted Papilloma should be considered when an elderly patient presents with unilateral nasal symptoms and imaging reveals a mass, especially when the presentation includes epistaxis and nasal obstruction without the severe pain or neurological symptoms that might suggest a more malignant etiology.

questions.text: A patient with Reinke’s edema will have which of the following symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Dysphonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reinke's edema primarily affects the vocal cords leading to characteristic symptoms related to voice changes where the patient may experience pain due to movement of swollen vocal cords. Heavy vocal cords require more effort by the vocal muscles to move them. Hence this extra effort of muscles causes pain and early vocal fatigue to the patient. Management involves addressing the underlying causes, surgical intervention, and supportive therapies like voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presents with right-sided serous otitis media and history of cervical lymphadenopathy. The probable diagnosis is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nasopharyngeal cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When an adult patient presents with serous otitis media and cervical lymphadenopathy, it is crucial to consider nasopharyngeal cancer as a possible diagnosis, especially in the context of risk factors such as age over 50 years and a history suggestive of malignancy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old was brought to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing since 2 hours. A radiograph was done as shown below. What will be the next step to manage the patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Esophagoscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In cases of suspected esophageal foreign bodies in children, esophagoscopy is the preferred method for both confirmation and removal of the object. It ensures that the foreign body is safely and effectively retrieved while minimizing risk to the patient.
  • ➤ esophagoscopy

questions.text: What is occipitomental view also known as? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Water’s view

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Water's view is crucial for diagnosing sinus-related pathologies, especially those affecting the maxillary and frontal sinuses. It is a fundamental technique in sinus imaging protocols, providing critical information for the diagnosis and management of sinus conditions.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of the tracheostomy tube shown in the image? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fenestration window

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows standard PVC tracheostomy tubes without fenestrations. Fenestrated tubes have a window or opening in the outer cannula to allow airflow through the larynx for phonation, which is not visible in these tubes. The tubes shown are:
  • • Made of thermosensitive PVC (becomes softer at body temperature) Have different colored caps indicating sizes Compatible with inner cannula (for cleaning) Suitable for prolonged mechanical ventilation
  • • Made of thermosensitive PVC (becomes softer at body temperature)
  • • Have different colored caps indicating sizes
  • • Compatible with inner cannula (for cleaning)
  • • Suitable for prolonged mechanical ventilation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Thermosensitive material - These are clearly PVC tubes which are thermosensitive, becoming softer at body temperature for patient comfort.
  • • Option A: Thermosensitive material
  • • Option C: Inner cannula - These tubes are compatible with inner cannulas, which can be removed for cleaning while maintaining airway patency.
  • • Option C: Inner cannula
  • • Option D: Prolonged mechanical ventilation compatibility - Standard PVC tracheostomy tubes are designed for long-term ventilation with appropriate connectors.
  • • Option D: Prolonged mechanical ventilation compatibility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Different types of tracheostomy tubes and their features Clinical applications of various tube designs Material properties of modern tracheostomy tubes Importance of tube selection based on patient needs Recognition of specific features like fenestration vs non-fenestration
  • ➤ Different types of tracheostomy tubes and their features
  • ➤ Clinical applications of various tube designs
  • ➤ Material properties of modern tracheostomy tubes
  • ➤ Importance of tube selection based on patient needs
  • ➤ Recognition of specific features like fenestration vs non-fenestration

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with unilateral hearing loss and fullness in the ear. Nasopharyngeal endoscopy shows the finding in the image. Which structure's pathology is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Opening of eustachian tube

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The endoscopic image shows the lateral wall of nasopharynx. The patient's symptoms of unilateral hearing loss and ear fullness strongly suggest eustachian tube dysfunction. The eustachian tube opening is located at the torus tubarius on the lateral nasopharyngeal wall. Obstruction or dysfunction of this opening leads to negative middle ear pressure and conductive hearing loss.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Fossa of Rosenmuller: While this is the depression posterior to the torus tubarius and is a critical anatomical landmark (being the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma), isolated pathology here wouldn't typically cause eustachian tube symptoms without adjacent involvement.
  • • Option A. Fossa of Rosenmuller:
  • • Option B. Tubal tonsil: Although hypertrophy can contribute to eustachian tube dysfunction, isolated tubal tonsil pathology is less common than primary eustachian tube opening problems.
  • • Option B. Tubal tonsil:
  • • Option D. Adenoid: Located on the posterior nasopharyngeal wall, not the lateral wall shown in the image. While adenoid hypertrophy can cause eustachian tube dysfunction, it typically presents bilaterally and is more common in children.
  • • Option D. Adenoid:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Anatomical relationships in the lateral nasopharyngeal wall Clinical correlation of eustachian tube dysfunction Differential diagnosis of unilateral hearing loss Importance of nasopharyngeal endoscopy in ear symptoms Recognition of normal nasopharyngeal landmarks
  • ➤ Anatomical relationships in the lateral nasopharyngeal wall
  • ➤ Clinical correlation of eustachian tube dysfunction
  • ➤ Differential diagnosis of unilateral hearing loss
  • ➤ Importance of nasopharyngeal endoscopy in ear symptoms
  • ➤ Recognition of normal nasopharyngeal landmarks

questions.text: A child as shown below presented to the ENT department with the following finding. She gives complaint of recurrent bony fractures along with reduced hearing. On further investigation, Tympanometry showed the following finding. What would you name this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Van der Hoeve syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The child presents with recurrent bony fractures and reduced hearing, which are indicative of osteogenesis imperfecta (imperfectly developed bones).
  • • The tympanometry shows an AS type of curve, suggesting otosclerosis.
  • • Additionally, the child has a blue sclera, which is a characteristic feature of osteogenesis imperfecta.
  • • This combination of symptoms — osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis — forms a triad known as Van der Hoeve syndrome.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Waardenburg syndrome: Waardenburg syndrome is characterized by congenital sensorineural hearing loss and pigmentary abnormalities such as a white forelock of hair (piebaldism).
  • • Option A. Waardenburg syndrome:
  • • Option C. Usher's syndrome: Usher's syndrome is associated with retinitis pigmentosa and congenital sensorineural hearing loss.
  • • Option C. Usher's syndrome:
  • • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • • Option D. Pendred syndrome: Pendred syndrome includes congenital sensorineural hearing loss and goiter.
  • • Option D. Pendred syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Van der Hoeve syndrome is characterized by the triad of osteogenesis imperfecta, blue sclera, and otosclerosis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of left ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Quinsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Quinsy is a severe infection requiring prompt recognition and treatment to prevent complications. It distinctly affects the peritonsillar area, leading to significant local and systemic symptoms that guide its diagnosis and management.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 299
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 299

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal obstruction after being hit on the face from the front. On examination, a boggy swelling of the septum is seen on both sides (see picture below), which is fluctuant on palpation with a swab or blunt probe. He should be managed by?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Incision & Drainage

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with nasal obstruction and a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum on both sides after trauma, which indicates a septal hematoma. A septal hematoma is a collection of blood within the septal tissues and requires immediate drainage to prevent complications such as infection, abscess formation, or septal cartilage necrosis. The definitive treatment is incision and drainage to evacuate the collected blood.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Nasal packing: Nasal packing is not the treatment of choice for a septal hematoma. It is typically used for controlling nasal bleeding (epistaxis).
  • • Option B. Nasal packing:
  • • Option C. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be used to prevent secondary infection, they do not address the primary issue of the hematoma and are not the definitive treatment.
  • • Option C. Antibiotics:
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants: Nasal decongestants are used to reduce nasal mucosal swelling and congestion but are not effective in treating a septal hematoma.
  • • Option D. Nasal decongestants:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A septal hematoma, characterized by a boggy, fluctuant swelling of the septum after nasal trauma, should be treated with immediate incision and drainage to prevent complications and ensure proper healing.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with progressive unilateral nasal obstruction for 6 months and occasional clear rhinorrhea. Transnasal endoscopic findings are shown in the image. CT scan shows a soft tissue mass extending from maxillary sinus through accessory ostium into the nasal cavity and choana. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Antrochoanal polyp

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation and imaging findings are characteristic of antrochoanal polyp. Key points supporting this diagnosis:
  • • Female patient (unlike JNA which occurs in adolescent males) Unilateral presentation No history of epistaxis Clear rhinorrhea rather than bleeding CT showing origin from maxillary sinus with typical extension pattern Endoscopic appearance showing smooth, pale mass
  • • Female patient (unlike JNA which occurs in adolescent males)
  • • Unilateral presentation
  • • No history of epistaxis
  • • Clear rhinorrhea rather than bleeding
  • • CT showing origin from maxillary sinus with typical extension pattern
  • • Endoscopic appearance showing smooth, pale mass
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Typically occurs in adolescent males, presents with epistaxis, and shows intense contrast enhancement on CT. The patient's gender and lack of bleeding make this unlikely.
  • • Option A. Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma:
  • • Option C. Rhinoscleroma: Presents with crusty discharge, tends to be bilateral, and shows characteristic histological features. CT would show more inflammatory changes.
  • • Option C. Rhinoscleroma:
  • • Option D. Concha bullosa: This is pneumatization of the middle turbinate, appears as an air-filled cavity on CT, and doesn't present as a mass extending into the choana.
  • • Option D. Concha bullosa:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Differential diagnosis of unilateral nasal masses Role of patient demographics in diagnosis Characteristic imaging patterns of different nasal pathologies Importance of endoscopic appearance in diagnosis Natural history and extension patterns of sinonasal polyps
  • ➤ Differential diagnosis of unilateral nasal masses
  • ➤ Role of patient demographics in diagnosis
  • ➤ Characteristic imaging patterns of different nasal pathologies
  • ➤ Importance of endoscopic appearance in diagnosis
  • ➤ Natural history and extension patterns of sinonasal polyps

questions.text: What type of stridor occur in croup?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Biphasic stridor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Croup typically presents with biphasic stridor, which occurs during both inspiration and expiration, reflecting the subglottic airway narrowing characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented to ENT OPD with severe dysphagia of recent onset and muffled voice. On examination, a cherry red swollen epiglottis was seen behind the tongue. On X-ray, the following finding is seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The child presents with severe dysphagia, a muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis, which are classic signs of acute epiglottitis. The X-ray shows the characteristic "thumb sign," indicating a swollen epiglottis. Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency and requires immediate attention. The child will typically sit in the tripod position to help keep the airway open.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis: Also known as croup, this condition typically presents with a barking cough and stridor. The X-ray shows the "steeple sign," which is not seen here.
  • • Option A. Acute laryngotracheobronchitis:
  • • Option C. Acute laryngitis: Acute laryngitis involves inflammation of the vocal cords, leading to hoarseness, but does not typically cause severe dysphagia or a swollen epiglottis.
  • • Option C. Acute laryngitis:
  • • Option D. Syphilis larynx: Syphilis affecting the larynx is rare and presents with different symptoms, such as hoarseness or a sore throat, rather than an acute swollen epiglottis.
  • • Option D. Syphilis larynx:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute epiglottitis presents with severe dysphagia, muffled voice, and a cherry red swollen epiglottis. The "thumb sign" on X-ray is a characteristic finding, and immediate medical intervention is necessary.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient developed severe respiratory distress within 6 hours postoperatively, with tense and painful anterior neck swelling. Repeated attempts at neck extension worsen the symptoms. The most probable cause is: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hematoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario suggests post-thyroidectomy hematoma because:
  • • Early onset (within 6-8 hours) of respiratory distress is typical Tense, painful neck swelling is characteristic Worsening with neck extension is a classic sign Immediate surgical evacuation is required to prevent airway compromise
  • • Early onset (within 6-8 hours) of respiratory distress is typical
  • • Tense, painful neck swelling is characteristic
  • • Worsening with neck extension is a classic sign
  • • Immediate surgical evacuation is required to prevent airway compromise
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury: Causes voice changes and aspiration but not acute neck swelling
  • • Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury:
  • • Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Results in hoarseness but not acute respiratory distress
  • • Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury:
  • • Option C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Presents with immediate post-operative extubation difficulty rather than progressive respiratory distress
  • • Option C. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-thyroidectomy hematoma is a surgical emergency requiring immediate evacuation Key distinguishing features include: Early onset (usually within 6-8 hours) Progressive neck swelling Pain and tension in neck Worsening with neck extension Time is critical - delay in recognition can lead to airway compromise Prevention includes meticulous hemostasis and close post-operative monitoring All post-thyroidectomy patients with respiratory symptoms need immediate evaluation to rule out hematoma
  • ➤ Post-thyroidectomy hematoma is a surgical emergency requiring immediate evacuation
  • ➤ Key distinguishing features include: Early onset (usually within 6-8 hours) Progressive neck swelling Pain and tension in neck Worsening with neck extension
  • ➤ Early onset (usually within 6-8 hours) Progressive neck swelling Pain and tension in neck Worsening with neck extension
  • ➤ Early onset (usually within 6-8 hours)
  • ➤ Progressive neck swelling
  • ➤ Pain and tension in neck
  • ➤ Worsening with neck extension
  • ➤ Time is critical - delay in recognition can lead to airway compromise
  • ➤ Prevention includes meticulous hemostasis and close post-operative monitoring
  • ➤ All post-thyroidectomy patients with respiratory symptoms need immediate evaluation to rule out hematoma

questions.text: What are the objective tests used to assess hearing? BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry) OAE (Otoacoustic emission) PTA (Pure tone audiometry) Tympanometry
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Objective tests such as BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic data without requiring any active response from the patient, thus suitable for use in patients who may not be able to respond reliably, such as young children or those with certain disabilities.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 25, 26, 29

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear

options.label: B
options.text: Rinne’s test positive , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

options.label: C
options.text: Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to left ear

options.label: D
options.text: Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

questions.correct_answer: D. Rinne’s test negative , Weber’s test lateralized to right ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rinne’s test negative, Weber’s test lateralized to right ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text: A teacher presented with complaints of hoarseness of voice. On examination, bilateral swelling was noted on anterior 1/3 rd and posterior 2/3 rd . What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Vocal nodule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vocal nodules are common in individuals who frequently use their voices intensely, and they require a combination of vocal rest, speech therapy, and possibly surgical intervention to manage effectively and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient with stage 2 supraglottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice but good airway and swallowing function. Recent 70-pack year smoking history. The patient has undergone following procedure in the ICU shown in the image. Which is the procedure being done in this patient?(Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B). Percutaneous tracheostomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows percutaneous tracheostomy which is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Partial laryngectomy: conservative surgery performed in supraglottic cancer to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.
  • • Option A. Partial laryngectomy:
  • • Option C. Standard tracheostomy: While visible in image, this is supportive care, not definitive cancer treatment.
  • • Option C. Standard tracheostomy:
  • • Option D. Total laryngectomy: Too radical for stage 2 supraglottic cancer with good function; would result in permanent stoma and loss of natural speech.
  • • Option D. Total laryngectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Surgical options for laryngeal cancer based on stage Principles of organ preservation surgery Role of temporary vs permanent tracheostomy Post-operative airway management Importance of functional status in surgical decision-making
  • ➤ Surgical options for laryngeal cancer based on stage
  • ➤ Principles of organ preservation surgery
  • ➤ Role of temporary vs permanent tracheostomy
  • ➤ Post-operative airway management
  • ➤ Importance of functional status in surgical decision-making

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. On examination, following was seen on the CECT. All are false except: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Bleeding is from the adjacent invading vessels

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tumor vessel lack contractility

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor vessels are known to lack contractility, which contributes to the risk of bleeding associated with tumors, as they cannot constrict effectively to stop blood flow when damaged.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on this image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kartagener syndrome is identified by the presence of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (including dextrocardia), which is clearly visible in the chest X-ray provided.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Young's operation is a unique surgical technique reserved for severe cases of atrophic rhinitis where other treatments have failed. This procedure helps in restoring the normal function and structure of the nasal mucosa by temporarily occluding the nostrils to allow healing.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 173
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 173

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with conductive hearing loss. CT temporal bone shows an isolated erosion of which ossicle shown in the image? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malleus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows the incus, but the question focuses on ossicular erosion patterns. In chronic otitis media, the lenticular process of the incus is most commonly eroded due to its tenuous blood supply. However, when there is isolated erosion of a single ossicle (without involvement of the incus), it typically affects the malleus head due to cholesteatoma in the epitympanum/attic region.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Incus: While incus is the most commonly eroded ossicle overall, isolated erosion of incus without involvement of other ossicles is rare due to its anatomical position and pattern of disease spread in chronic otitis media.
  • • Option B. Incus:
  • • Option C. Stapes: Isolated stapes erosion is extremely rare. When stapes is involved, it's usually in conjunction with incus erosion due to the contiguous spread of disease.
  • • Option C. Stapes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the patterns of ossicular erosion in chronic otitis media and cholesteatoma, with emphasis on:
  • ➤ The blood supply of ossicles The pattern of disease spread in the middle ear Clinical correlation with types of hearing loss Importance of imaging in determining extent of disease
  • ➤ The blood supply of ossicles
  • ➤ The pattern of disease spread in the middle ear
  • ➤ Clinical correlation with types of hearing loss
  • ➤ Importance of imaging in determining extent of disease

questions.text: A 35-year-old female took aspirin for headache and she developed wheezing and breathlessness. This will be associated with? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Nasal Polyp

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognizing the link between aspirin ingestion and respiratory symptoms in patients with nasal polyps is crucial for managing their condition effectively. Patients diagnosed with AERD should avoid NSAIDs and may need specific treatments for asthma and nasal polyps, along with alternatives to NSAIDs for pain management.
  • ➤ Samter’s triad: Asthma, Nasal polyposis (ethmoidal), Aspirin hypersensitivity

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 166
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: What test is not used for testing olfaction? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arnold stick test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tests used for olfaction are as follows:
  • ➤ Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient. University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets. The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT) , is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes. The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.
  • ➤ Smell diskettes are used as a screening test for olfaction. Reusable diskettes are used with the application of 8 different odorants. A questionnaire with illustrations is used to score the patient.
  • ➤ Smell diskettes
  • ➤ University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) is a commercially available, self-administered test used to assess the function of an individual's olfactory system via smell identification. It uses microencapsulated odorants, which are released on scratching standardized odor-impregnated test booklets.
  • ➤ University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)
  • ➤ The 12-item version of UPSIT, also known as the Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT) , is useful for quantifying smell loss when less time is available. This test serves as a means to reliably assess olfactory function in less than 5 minutes.
  • ➤ Cross-Cultural Smell Identification Test (CC-SIT)
  • ➤ The Sniffin' Sticks test is a new test of nasal chemosensory performance based on pen-like odor-dispensing devices. Semi-objective assessment of the patient's olfactory performance by means of 3 subtests: threshold test, identification test and discrimination test.
  • ➤ The Sniffin' Sticks
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233
  • ➤ Ref - Scott Brown 8 th edition, volume 2, Page No. 1233

questions.text: Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: ( INICET Nov 2020) Cochlear nucleus Spiral ganglion Superior olivary nucleus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.
  • ➤ The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve Cochlear Nucleus Superior Olivary nucleus Lateral lemniscus Inferior colliculus Medial geniculate body Auditory cortex
  • ➤ Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  • ➤ Cochlear Nucleus
  • ➤ Superior Olivary nucleus
  • ➤ Lateral lemniscus
  • ➤ Inferior colliculus
  • ➤ Medial geniculate body
  • ➤ Auditory cortex
  • ➤ The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with known Samter's triad presents with severe migraine. After successful aspirin desensitization therapy 6 months ago, he has been on daily aspirin maintenance. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ketorolac

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In a patient who has undergone aspirin desensitization for Samter's triad, the key consideration is maintaining the desensitized state.
  • • Key points:
  • • Key points:
  • • After successful aspirin desensitization, patients must continue daily aspirin therapy to maintain the desensitized state Introduction of other COX-1 inhibitors (like ketorolac) can trigger severe reactions even in desensitized patients Non-COX-1 inhibiting pain medications are safe to use
  • • After successful aspirin desensitization, patients must continue daily aspirin therapy to maintain the desensitized state
  • • Introduction of other COX-1 inhibitors (like ketorolac) can trigger severe reactions even in desensitized patients
  • • Non-COX-1 inhibiting pain medications are safe to use
  • • The mechanism behind this involves:
  • • The mechanism behind this involves:
  • • Aspirin desensitization modifies leukotriene production pathways specifically for aspirin Other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1 can still trigger reactions through independent pathways This is why even desensitized patients must avoid other NSAIDs
  • • Aspirin desensitization modifies leukotriene production pathways specifically for aspirin
  • • Other NSAIDs that inhibit COX-1 can still trigger reactions through independent pathways
  • • This is why even desensitized patients must avoid other NSAIDs
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acetaminophen : Safe to use as it has minimal COX-1 inhibition and is generally well-tolerated in aspirin-sensitive patients.
  • • Option A. Acetaminophen
  • • Option C. Sumatriptan : A triptan medication that works through serotonin receptors and is safe for migraine treatment in these patients.
  • • Option C. Sumatriptan
  • • Option D. Topiramate : An anticonvulsant used for migraine prophylaxis that doesn't affect COX pathways.
  • • Option D. Topiramate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding that aspirin desensitization in Samter's triad doesn't confer protection against other NSAIDs, and recognizing safe alternative pain management options in these patients.

questions.text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supraglottic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inspiratory stridor is a key clinical sign indicating a potential obstruction in the supraglottic region of the airway. Recognizing this symptom is critical for diagnosing and managing airway obstructions effectively to prevent respiratory distress.
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 333, 334
  • ➤ Ref - Dhingra 7 th edition, Page No. 333, 334

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with severe ear pain and tenderness over the mastoid area following tooth extraction and jaw manipulation. Post-procedure examination shows no middle ear pathology. Which nerve is most likely responsible for the referred pain? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Auriculotemporal nerve

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The auriculotemporal nerve (V3) is most likely responsible in this case because:
  • • It's a branch of mandibular nerve that provides sensory innervation to TMJ, parotid region, and anterior part of ear Dental procedures and jaw manipulation can irritate this nerve Its anatomical course makes it susceptible to compression or irritation during dental procedures The distribution matches the patient's symptoms
  • • It's a branch of mandibular nerve that provides sensory innervation to TMJ, parotid region, and anterior part of ear
  • • Dental procedures and jaw manipulation can irritate this nerve
  • • Its anatomical course makes it susceptible to compression or irritation during dental procedures
  • • The distribution matches the patient's symptoms
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve: While important for referred otalgia, it's primarily involved in pharyngeal pathology rather than dental/TMJ issues.
  • • Option A. Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve:
  • • Option B. Greater auricular nerve: Though it supplies the mastoid area, it originates from C2,3 and isn't directly affected by dental procedures.
  • • Option B. Greater auricular nerve:
  • • Option D. Auricular branch of vagus nerve: Supplies the concha and antihelix, but isn't typically involved in dental procedure-related pain.
  • • Option D. Auricular branch of vagus nerve:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand:
  • ➤ Pathways of referred ear pain Nerve distribution in the ear and temporal region Clinical correlation with dental procedures Differential diagnosis of otalgia Anatomical basis of TMJ-related ear symptoms
  • ➤ Pathways of referred ear pain
  • ➤ Nerve distribution in the ear and temporal region
  • ➤ Clinical correlation with dental procedures
  • ➤ Differential diagnosis of otalgia
  • ➤ Anatomical basis of TMJ-related ear symptoms

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with hearing loss. On examination, a white pearly mass is seen behind an intact TM as shown below. There is no history of TM perforation or surgery. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Congenital cholesteatoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in a young child with no history of tympanic membrane perforation or surgery strongly suggests congenital cholesteatoma. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs due to the presence of residual epithelial cells trapped within the middle ear during embryogenesis, which later proliferate. This condition is typically seen in the anterosuperior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Primary cholesteatoma: Primary cholesteatoma usually involves a retraction pocket and is associated with a history of eustachian tube dysfunction. It is not typically seen with an intact tympanic membrane without a history of perforation or retraction.
  • • Option B. Primary cholesteatoma:
  • • Option C. Secondary cholesteatoma: Secondary cholesteatoma arises due to chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) with tympanic membrane perforation or from a previous surgical procedure. It does not present with an intact tympanic membrane.
  • • Option C. Secondary cholesteatoma:
  • • Option D. Tubotympanic CSOM: Tubotympanic chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is associated with a central perforation of the tympanic membrane and chronic discharge. It is not consistent with an intact tympanic membrane and a white pearly mass.
  • • Option D. Tubotympanic CSOM:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital cholesteatoma is characterized by a white pearly mass behind an intact tympanic membrane in the absence of any history of perforation or surgery. It is typically found in the anterosuperior quadrant of the middle ear.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis for the past 6 months. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) JNA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with right-sided nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis, as it commonly presents in adolescent males with these symptoms.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with hoarseness of voice with a history of significant weight loss. On laryngoscopy, ulceroproliferative growth involving the left vocal fold is seen, as shown below. The vocal cord is fixed. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation (hoarseness of voice, weight loss) and the laryngoscopic findings (ulceroproliferative growth with fixed vocal cord) suggest advanced glottic carcinoma. The fixed vocal cord indicates at least T3 stage, as it suggests tumor infiltration into the paraglottic space or fixation due to deeper invasion. Weight loss in an elderly patient further supports an advanced stage malignancy.
  • • This is the preferred treatment for T3 or T4 laryngeal cancers, especially when the vocal cords are fixed, and there is a high likelihood of regional spread. If the patient has significant lymph node involvement or is symptomatic (e.g., weight loss), a neck dissection is warranted along with total laryngectomy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Radical Radiotherapy: Radical radiotherapy is usually preferred for early-stage laryngeal cancers (T1 or T2) with mobile vocal cords. It is less effective for advanced stages (T3 or T4) due to higher chances of recurrence.
  • • Option A. Radical Radiotherapy:
  • • Option C. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy alone is not the primary treatment for advanced laryngeal carcinoma unless the patient is unsuitable for surgery or radiation. It is primarily used for palliative care or in cases with distant metastasis.
  • • Option C. Chemotherapy:
  • • Option D. Concurrent Chemoradiation: Concurrent chemoradiation is a consideration for organ preservation in advanced laryngeal cancers. However, for patients with a fixed vocal cord and significant weight loss, total laryngectomy provides better local control and survival outcomes.
  • • Option D. Concurrent Chemoradiation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For advanced glottic carcinoma with vocal cord fixation (T3/T4) and evidence of regional spread, the best treatment option is Total Laryngectomy with Neck Dissection.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown on x-ray. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Double ring sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The double ring sign on an x-ray indicates the presence of a button battery in the esophagus, distinguished by two concentric rings, which is critical to identify promptly due to the potential for severe complications.

questions.text: Which is the best stain for biopsy during laryngoscopy for vocal cord examination? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supravital

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toluidine blue, a supravital stain, is the best stain for non-invasive detection of cancerous growths during laryngoscopy of the vocal cords due to its high uptake by cells with active DNA and RNA synthesis.
  • ➤ Toluidine blue, a supravital stain, is the best stain for non-invasive detection of cancerous growths during laryngoscopy of the vocal cords

questions.text: A 25-year-old brought to the emergency department with complaints of mild bloody rhinorrhea. On examination, he was awake and oriented. Drainage has soiled his shirt, and the appearance of which is given below. This is seen in case of: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Traumatic CSF Rhinorrhea

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with mild bloody rhinorrhea, and the drainage has created a characteristic "halo sign" or "double ring sign" on his shirt. This sign indicates the presence of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) mixed with blood. The halo sign is seen when CSF forms a clear ring around a central bloody spot on absorbent material. This finding is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where trauma causes a breach in the meninges, allowing CSF to leak and mix with nasal secretions or blood.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea: Spontaneous CSF rhinorrhea typically involves clear CSF leakage without blood. The absence of blood would not produce the halo sign as described.
  • • Option B. Spontaneous CSF Rhinorrhea:
  • • Option C. Meningocele: Meningocele involves herniation of the meninges through a defect in the skull or spinal column but does not typically cause nasal CSF leakage mixed with blood. It usually presents as a mass or bulge.
  • • Option C. Meningocele:
  • • Option D. Tumors: Tumors might cause nasal discharge, but the presence of a halo sign specifically points to a CSF leak, which is more characteristic of traumatic causes rather than tumors.
  • • Option D. Tumors:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The halo sign or double ring sign on absorbent material is indicative of traumatic CSF rhinorrhea, where CSF leaks and mixes with blood, creating a central red spot surrounded by a clear or yellowish ring.

questions.text: A patient presents with repeated infections from the lesion shown in the image. The correct statement in relation to the image is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Derived from pouch of 1 st and 2 nd arches

options.label: C
options.text: Derived from 1 st and 2 nd arches

options.label: D
options.text: Derived from 3 rd and 4 th arches

questions.correct_answer: C. Derived from 1 st and 2 nd arches
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Derived from 1stand 2ndarches

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preauricular sinuses or cysts are congenital lesions derived from the first and second branchial arches and are associated with the external ear, often presenting with recurrent infections

questions.text: A 7-year-old male presents to the ER with a two-day history of worsening ear pain and drainage. He was evaluated in the clinic 5 days ago and diagnosed with acute right otitis media. He was placed on amoxicillin and he initially appeared to improve until two days ago when his ear pain recurred and this is now accompanied by ear drainage, redness behind his right ear, and a prominent right pinna which is pointing down and out as shown below. The most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute Mastoiditis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute mastoiditis, a complication of acute otitis media, can present with post-auricular redness, abscess, and displacement of the pinna, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A patient presents with painful vesicles on the tympanic membrane and in the external auditory meatus, accompanied by features of facial nerve palsy. What is the diagnosis and which site is affected?

options.label: A
options.text: Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

options.label: B
options.text: Ramsay hunt syndrome and basal ganglion

questions.correct_answer: A. Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ramsay hunt syndrome and geniculate ganglion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ramsay Hunt syndrome is a reactivation of herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion, leading to a characteristic vesicular eruption on the ear and facial nerve palsy. Early recognition and treatment are vital to prevent complications and improve recovery.
